online.game
Interface ViewGameProtocol

All Known Subinterfaces:
ViewerProtocol
All Known Implementing Classes:
CheckerGameViewer, commonCanvas, GoViewer, HexGameViewer, TabGameViewer
public interface ViewGameProtocol

these protocol items are normally of concern only to the Game class. these are low level services provided to viewers in conjunction with the game. These methods may be wrapped or overridden by the viewer class, but are not expected or required to be.

Author:
ddyer

Method Detail

changePlayerList

void changePlayerList(commonPlayer p,
                      commonPlayer replace)
add a new player to the list of commonPlayers, replace the one specified, which may be null, meaning assign the next empty slot. If both are null clear the player list. This is used by the Game to keep the Viewer informed of the identities of the players.

Parameters:
p - the player to add, or null to remove
replace - the player to replace, or null to assign a new slot.

spritesIdle

boolean spritesIdle()
return the number of animation steps that are still pending. This is used to determine that the viewer is idle and finished all the end of game displays

changeSpectatorList

void changeSpectatorList(commonPlayer p,
                         commonPlayer replace)
add a new spectator to the list of commonPlayers, replace the one specified, which may be null, meaning assign the next empty slot. If both are null clear the player list. This is used by the Game to keep the Viewer informed of the identities of the Spectators. In review rooms, there are only spectators.

Parameters:
p - the player to add, or null to remove
replace - the player to replace, or null to assign a new slot.

doMouseTracking

void doMouseTracking(commonPlayer player,
                     java.lang.String zone,
                     int inx,
                     int iny,
                     int ino)
Record the latest mouse tracking information about the player (or spectator). only remembering, no other action, should occur. By convention, record nothing if player happens to be self. Also by convention, if inx is >=0 it reflects an object begin moved by the player, and all the other players should be set to not be moving. By convention, there is at most one moving object in the game at any time.

Parameters:
player - the player, or spectator.
zone - default "on" "board" or "off", or whatever means something to your viewer
inx - encoded x coordinate
iny - encoded y coordinate
ino - if >=0 represents an object being moved.

setVisible

void setVisible(boolean val)
viewers are created in a not-yet-visible state, this method tells them to become visible. This allows messy startup phases to be invisible.

errorContext

java.lang.String errorContext()
return any interesting information for debugging and logging. This is used to get interesting information into the logs to help debug difficult problems.

allRobotsIdle

boolean allRobotsIdle()
return true if there are no robots actively running

Returns:
true is no robots are running

updatePlayerTime

void updatePlayerTime(long currentT,
                      commonPlayer whoseTurn)
update the player time, normally for the current player only

stopRobots

void stopRobots()
stop all robots. This is done by traversing the list of players.

startRobotTurn

void startRobotTurn(commonPlayer p)
if there is a robot player for this player, start it running to make the next move.

setLimbo

void setLimbo(boolean v)
set the viewer into "limbo" state, where no moves can be made. This is probably due to an involuntary interruption of the game, such as a loss of communications

setUserMessage

void setUserMessage(java.awt.Color c,
                    java.lang.String m)
set a message which will be seen by the user. These are normally related to game events such as "waiting for other players". This should override routine game advice which might share the same space. This message is eventually made visible in the GUI by standardGameMessage

ParseMessage

boolean ParseMessage(java.lang.String st)
parse and execute a message which originated in a getEvents string. Return true if the message was successfully parsed in the game main sequence, false if some error or if a review variation

ParseEcho

boolean ParseEcho(java.lang.String str)
same as ParseMessage, but for strings that are the echo of commands from us

Parameters:
str -
Returns:
true if all ok

getEvents

java.util.Vector<java.lang.String> getEvents()
get a vector of strings, which are events that should be sent to spectators and other players. These events will be presented to other viewers of the same class to be interpreted and executed. These "events" are normally moves or gestures, but not individual mouse positions (mouse tracking sprites are handled automatically)

PerformAndTransmit

boolean PerformAndTransmit(java.lang.String st)
this is used to insert moves by robots into the game "as though" they resulted from a user interface action

processMessage

boolean processMessage(java.lang.String cmd,
                       java.util.StringTokenizer localST,
                       java.lang.String st)
first chance to process a message. Normally just ignore. This is a way for a game to intercept messages sent outside of the normal mechanism

setEditable

void setEditable()
declare now it is ok to edit the game record. During normal play, editing the game record is not allowed. After game end, players are free to go back and play variations. This method will be called after the game is over and scoring activity has completed.

setControlToken

void setControlToken(boolean val,
                     long timestamp)
set who has control to make editing moves. This is handled by the game controler. There is no UI, but the viewer should respect hasControlToken()

hasControlTokenOrPending

boolean hasControlTokenOrPending()
say if we think we have the control token

startPlaying

void startPlaying()
called when setup is complete and we're ready to start. At this point the user interface becomes live and moves may arrive from other players.

hasExplicitControlToken

boolean hasExplicitControlToken()
true if we have the server-defined control token, so might benefit by giving it up.

Returns:
a boolean

printDebugInfo

void printDebugInfo(java.io.PrintStream s)
print debugging info for the error log. This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class

doLoadUrl

void doLoadUrl(java.lang.String name,
               java.lang.String gamename)
Load a file, presumably full of game records in SGF format. This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class.

selectGame

boolean selectGame(java.lang.String selected)
Select and set up to replay a game which has been loaded. This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class, which records the activity for later action by the viewerRun loop

doScrollTo

boolean doScrollTo(int val)
scroll the game to a position, identified by getReviewPosition in another viewer This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class, which records the activity for later action by the viewerRun loop

setJointReviewStep

void setJointReviewStep(int v)
set the requested review position This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class, which records the activity for later action by the viewerRun loop

getReviewPosition

int getReviewPosition()
get the current actual review position This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class, which records the activity for later action by the viewerRun loop

getJointReviewStep

int getJointReviewStep()
get the current requested review position. -2 indicates don't know This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class, which records the activity for later action by the viewerRun loop

MoveStep

int MoveStep()
return the true move number of the game (ie: not the review mode move number). This is used only for a few non-critacl things such as guessing if the game has really started, or if it is still in setup phase, and to determine if the game has reached midpoint.

whoseTurn

commonPlayer whoseTurn()
return the player whose turn it is. This is used to switch the game state to reflect the current player. Some actions (for example supplying the current state of the game to new spectators) are only performed by the current player. This is also the trigger for "turn change" sounds.

getMovingObject

int getMovingObject()
get the identity of the object being dragged by the mouse, or null. This is an arbitrary integer which matters only to other instances of the same type of viewer.

addObserver

java.util.Observable addObserver(java.util.Observer o)
required by the observer protocol This service is normally completely covered by the commonCanvas class, which records the activity for later action by the viewerRun loop

doTime

void doTime(commonPlayer whoseTurn,
            boolean doSound)
do time related things during a game

printGameRecord

void printGameRecord(java.io.PrintStream s,
                     java.lang.String startingTime,
                     java.lang.String filename)
print the game record as a SGF file. These are "public" rather than private formats, but mainly to be parsed by the reviewer version of the viewer.

formEphemeralHistoryString

java.lang.String formEphemeralHistoryString()
return a short string reflecting any ephmeral (rapidly changing) state of the game, for example the next player to play. You can alter the default method if you make corresponding adjustments in the useEphemeralBuffer method. Recommended practice is to tack a parseable preamble onto the standard string.

useEphemeraBuffer

void useEphemeraBuffer(java.util.StringTokenizer mySt)
playback the ephemeral data supplied by formEphemeralString.

Parameters:
mySt -

formStoryString

java.lang.String formStoryString()
return a history string which will allow another viewer (as player or spectator) to replay the game. This is used to get new spectators up to date with the state of the game. This string should be as brief as possible to minimize bandwidth, and should grow by adding new stuff to the end, so only the end of the string needs to be transmitted. The defaullt method uses the move history to generate a printable/parseable representation of the game.

useStoryBuffer

void useStoryBuffer(java.lang.String tok,
                    java.util.StringTokenizer mySt)
interpret a history string as created by formHistoryString. The contract is to bring the local game into the same state as the game that created the string. This is used to give spectators the view of the game, and also to reconnect players that have been disconnected.

enableSynchronization

void enableSynchronization(boolean d)
If the server can be enabled to synchronize asynchronous moves this set true.

Parameters:
d -

playerChanging

boolean playerChanging()
called when the game controller detects that the current player is changing to your player. If this methods returns true, the road runner "beep beep" or "turnchange" sound is played.
